title: My friend got into a club, but not me? How?
content:
It was a tech club. Although I know programming and had better answers than him for the questions, i did not get in and he did. He does not know any programming and copy pasted answers from chatgpt. I have nothing against him but I feel bad because I thought I had the potential. 

As there are less clubs recruiting now, I'm scared I won't get into a tech club. I really want to.

comments.body: Which year you are in?

Yes, I do agree that the selection process is pretty stupid.
The entire point of the clubs is to meet like-minded people and make good friends along the way but by not having a good selection criteria and process, you are demotivating who are definitely qualified for the clubs. The fact that a club even needs a selection process in the first place sounds dumb. What if I'm really passionate about films and am a film geek but I can't apply for the club just because I haven't actually made any short films by myself?

I'm very frustrated with the clubs right now too. I decided to apply for the cinematography post in the filmmaking club. Considering that I had already directed two short films I assumed that it would be easy but turns out you have to direct a one minute long campaign/advertisement. The campaign does sound relevant but if you asked me what would be a more relevant selection criteria, I would say that it is short films. Even if I decide to upload my short film in place of the campaign, I have to ensure that the file is under 10 mb, which is impossible.

The entire point of the clubs is to meet like-minded people and make good friends along the way but by not having a good selection criteria and process, you are demotivating who are definitely qualified for the clubs.

Chill dude. I applied for the ML domain in a CS club. Ik some ML despite being non-cs, I even answered their questions correctly. They even took my Github ID to see projects, I had one project in ML. And I still got rejected, simply because my knowledge wasn't as extensive and they felt that learning ML will be 'hard for me', In the group they said they didn't want technical answers and proceeded to ask technical questions where I gave partially technical answers almost to the point. Idk what their agenda was, but I did not get in. Don't break your head, focus on your own projects, they carry more value, and trust me, once u join a club u will be tasked to do all kinds of odd jobs u won't like. Take part in club events, and let them serve you instead of you serving them.
